7Mj60OLZovGMXwgU2Ba6Lw.text: From the outside it may not look like much but Kebab Mahal does some of the best curries in Edinburgh.

y4PpDzKodtz_BTEdvveV2w.text: My colleague and I have been going to Kebab Mahal once a week for almost three years now. In that time my appreciation of good food has substantially increased, my tolerance of chilli has sky-rocketed, and my stomach has doubtless swelled to accommodate their generous helpings of curry and monster nans!   Without wanting to sound cliched, Kebab Mahal is all about the food. From the outside it looks totally uninspiring; the decor on the inside is pedestrian (it's basically a takeaway with some tables). What you will notice however is the comforting mix of people, including many 'local types' who obviously go there all the time, rubbing shoulders (sometimes literally) as they eat. Throughout, the genial manager Mr Khan and his staff move unhurriedly, attending to the thronging clientele as they can. One of the refreshing things about Kebab Mahal is its authenticity. The ownership makes no bones about its Muslim identity (there is no booze and Friday lunchtimes are closed for prayers), but it does so in a way that is reassuringly natural.   Returning to the food, the one gripe I have about Kebab Mahal is their extremely limited menu. Visit any regular curry takeaway and you will be presented with a list of 'Old Favourites' or the like (from Korma to Vindaloo), next to a somewhat longer list of 'specialities'. Invariably these turn out to differ little in taste or appearance. At Kebab Mahal the selection is admittedly small, but each curry is a thoroughly distinct 'beast'. The Pathia is thin and sticky (don't let that description put you off!), the Ceylon is packed with coconut and when you order a lentil dish like Dhansak a lentil dish is very much what you get. The last two aren't even on the menu, but the staff take such orders (including those for the uber-hot Phall) in their stride. I haven't gone out of my way to test Mr Khan and his staff on their menu flexibility, but I guess they can pretty much back up their claim to cook curry dishes to order. The other thing I would draw attention to is the lamb, in that it really doesn't taste like lamb. And this is a good thing!  I'd be perfectly willing to believe it was a different animal altogether, whose flesh is entirely preferable to that of lamb. Finally, the taste of the curries is almost always divine (packed with flavour as Masterchef's John and Gregg would say), although an abundance of oil sometimes make an unwelcome appearance. The reviewer on a different site who said this is the best restaurant in the world: he can't be far wrong!

QfXb7OyKOG3CnvRZez9AJQ.text: I absolutely love Kebab Mahal - the food is fantastic, it's cheap and the staff are friendly. I even enjoy the low key decor and diner style. It's a well known must-eat in Edinburgh for students, tourists and professionals alike. The only reason it misses out a star is because of the lack of seating and sometimes late service. However, it all adds to it's charm. Situated in Edinburgh's south side, on Nicholson square, well known for it's Desi and Middle Eastern food joints as well as the Mosque Kitchen, 'closed for prayer on Friday', Kebab Mahal is one of Edinburgh's best.

gB32bcC43JF8LkLWqxjbxQ.text: I love that this place has looked the same for as long as I can remember. I hate it when places like this get a good name for themselves, make a bit of money, and then think it is a good idea to completely refurb, ruining the atmosphere.  It is cheap and cheerful and the kebabs and curries are some of the best I've had.

pKpfydEjVFrVkORxChvykg.text: This place finds a mention in two travel guides and so my expectations were high. It did not fail me as far as food is concerned but service, interiors and ambience need an overhaul! Kebabs and tikkas are succulent and delicious. Vegetarian side dishes can be asked for in main course portions and they are really good. Baigan bhaji, dal, aloo gobhi in particular. Their snacks (pakora, samosa etc) lack flavour and are best avoided. I would have rated this place higher if their service was better. On more than 2 occasions the waiter brought the wrong order or ignored a special request.

photos.caption: Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

CBoDO1qroTpLjyIW_a8WLg.text: The curries are so hot in this place that even the onion bhajis were too hot for me! Really cheap, great curry if you can take the heat. Good for both take out and eating in, but it's quite small.

pRRxJWbSrbWg1AZkiHuD3g.text: Edinburgh has a whole host of kebab shops, probably even hundreds. It can be very difficult to tell the difference between them as they are expensive and most taste the same.   However, Kebab Mehal is different. This Turkish diner provides gives you with an excellent portion for a much cheaper price than you would usually expect and it tastes much better. Furthermore, there is a bigger portion of salad so you can even fool yourself into thinking you has a healthy meal. This Turkish restaurant even serves quality food outside kebabs and there were even vegetarian options last time I was there. Finally on both my three visits the standard of hygiene and speed of service have been excellent.   It provides a great meal to end any quality night out on a high note!!

c3Z4t1MUeWCLwiHjoXaj4A.text: Great for a quick lunch. So tasty. Best kebabs in Edinburgh. Service a bit slow but hey, it's busy for a reason. Small spot- not great for a large group.

CyfTHflNRKmSc7rdjdsRzA.text: Another amazing trip to Kebab Mahal. The lovely staff and killer food makes this place a secret Edinburgh must.

6sRwgF6una80a42N3S7rPw.text: fantasies of you are inspiring me to finish my phd proposal that will be the only hope of our reunion.   please don't change. except maybe you could get more tables. and do delivery. and revamp the toilets.   but nothing else.   if i don't get accepted, or funding,  i will be your US rep and together we will conquer a country of generally mediocre indian food.  xxoo

Non2UoqZ2EuIHggDWunlRQ.text: I visited Kebab Mahal for the first time this last week and really loved it. We went there on recommendation from a friend who said they do delicious kebabs and as we arrived people were sat outside eating a variety of curries.   So what intended to be a quick trip to buy a kebab ended up with us buying two plates of curry, two bowls of rice, an awesome nan bread and a drink. The curry was really delicious, I had a lamb curry which didn't have a lamb taste but nonetheless tasted delicious. My partner had a chicken curry and she asked for chilli's to be added which they did. The nan bread was awesome. It was freshly cooked and had mince in the middle.   So again what started as a trip for a kebab ended up with a feast and we still bought a large chicken tikka kebab (which we intended to save until the next day but ended up eating after we got home).   Kebab Mahal along with Mosque Kitchen are easily my two favourite curry shops in Edinburgh.   Service was pretty quick for our main food although we had to wait a while while our kebab was cooked, which is fair enough. A note if you're visiting, this place became absolutely packed out just after we arrived. We managed to order straight away but just after we sat down there were four or five people waiting to order. A testimony to how good the food is.

X4RPRqOCc2gOtKST_nIqpA.text: Service in here is slow. It's mostly a takeaway, but also a diner with a few tables. If you want to eat in; most of the time you'll have to wait or maybe share a table. The above is just proof of how busy this place is  and for good reason. Packed with all types of people until late, the food in here is delicious and cheap. A large range of curries are made with the most tender chicken and lamb or veg if that's your thing  you'll never have a piece of fatty or tough chicken/lamb in here, which is a lot more than can be said for a lot of Edinburgh curry joints. Other mains include a selection of biryanis. The rice is pure buttery goodness, and a large variety of breads are on offer. Also on offer are pakoras, chaat, kebab, samosas and other tandoori starters. From midnight  2am, pizzas, kebabs and starters are served. For dessert pick up indian ice cream, and other pastries and sweets such as Paklava (Baklawa), Gulab Jammun, Baba baba, Rasmalai or have some lassi or tea to finish your meal. The atmosphere in here is buzzed, the decor simple and honest with regulars and visitors as Kebab Mahal is often cited as worth a visit to Edinburgh's Southside, where you'll find plenty of international and ethnic diners and takeaways.

Cl8oQrSU4IG2QM289FKkqA.text: Why oh why have you led so far astray yelp!?  This hole in the wall restaurant was to be a great secret delicious place, instead it turned out that it was a filthy hovel with terrible starch to fill the belly.  Waiters with foul yellow stains from their own food eating misadventures, meat sitting in unrefridgerated counters and a dining room that resembled the boiler room from a b horror film.  The food was not cheap in comparison to some amazing restaurants we enjoyed at lunch such as mussel and steak just a short walk away. I know this is supposedly a good place for university students but I would gladly go back to Ramon noodles and fluorescent Mac and cheese.  They seat you at a dingy table while you contemplate running out before someone notices you and then man with a untucked shirt with stains and an unkempt beard asks for your order. The smell of stale food and dry spices fill the nostrils and then the food arrives. Rice that's lukewarm and veggies straight from the freezer in spices to hide the freezer burn taste. Singed bread that is cool as well and soon you wonder if all they have in the kitchen is a freezer, a toaster and an old microwave. The bill is not printed out but rather shown to you on a calculator... Hmm I wonder why... Do yourself a favor and call the health inspector on this Burke and Hare show they call an Indian restaurant. Run

QQwX6uDZPJTqPMAH6YMgzA.text: The food from this restaurant is just amazing coming from a desi myself. The taste, oiliness and everything is just perfect. I have only opted for takeaways so far but I have seen couple of crowds at the place. The restaurant atmosphere is very humble but if you are a fussy person like me I wouldn't recommend sitting in. Just have it to go and enjoy the deliciousness!

QICLABdOnLb52NR073b6Bw.text: I haven't had much Middle Eastern/Indian  food at all and very unfamiliar with it all. I went in for a Donner kebab and ordered the wrong thing (I know I'm a novice). I can't remember what I got but it was spicy, rich and cooked perfectly. Not to mention the Naan Bread was cooked fresh in the back and was to die for. It does get busy but it only shows how good it truly is. reasonably priced for the quality too!  I can't wait to go back!

o39yZJaaTOweqq6Ae5PWwg.text: Awesome - even though I wasn't too adventurous with tikka masala (which is my gold standard to compare others to), it was fantastic.  Service was excellent and the price was just right.

v5wM8O90EOz6vT4QlJJp_w.text: large portions, good prices, and it tastes great. If you are looking for a good curry or kebab, then this is your place. I can't imagine there's a better place in all of Edinburgh. Cheap and casual.

-luxXHlpPLRfmud8GtVjDA.text: Went to Kebab Mahal during a visit to the Fringe for a snack. I love the mixed pakora which is served with salad & sauce. (Cheaper then you'll get at any of the Fringe venues)We ate in the garden outside the shop as it was mobbed. The interior is not in a great decorative state but any time I have hjad food from here it has been excellant. Try it for yourself & see!

ssY4HZ0NcoeqH2h3_BQuoA.text: nice place great kebabs and spicey. fairly friendly and very easy to access. The square outside recently got rennovated and is looking beautifull now but please dont dump your rubbish in the nice new square as some people do. Nice spicy curries and kebabs for delivery or eat ins.

maL-P7a1wmSoYO4u968Jkw.text: Hands down, this is the best value in Edinburgh.  I don't know about their kebabs, but the curries are excellent and really very cheap. I usually eat the veggie curries but have also had a few of the lamb curries.  Service is terribly slow but the food is so good you learn to love it. I have been going for years and will keep going for years to come.

RJBorkAMgB2MW3ICz6LSEw.text: Really good curries for cheap prices. This is a takeaway but there are some seats in the back. The portions are good sized and if you are veggie the veg side dishes are nice as a main course. The garlic naans are really delicious.

YI3IVhiMCvVw8RDaqAhEWQ.text: If in Edinburgh you must visit the Kebab Mahal. The food is tremendous and the best Indian food you will taste in the whole of the city! The price is just as amazing as the food! I defy you to find anything cheaper. The atmosphere is brilliant and very popular with students with the University near by. Stop by and check it out! You will go back again and again.

03xTm2WXyx8QO0f70vuI7w.text: Need a cheap meal, then this is the place to go! Great sized curry for 4 -5- was yummy too. Super unfriendly and unhelpful staff though. Cleanliness of the place was a bit gross. Our table hadn't  been wiped and floors looked like they hadn't been mopped in a year!

zCl0JZO34ntlmk2bseqMDw.text: Right, so after my last review of Kebab Mahal, I decided that I was hungry. So I went back to Kebab Mahal, of course!  This time I went for the lamb-curry something I hadn't tried before and, being Indonesian and curry-prone myself, I think I died of bliss.  I shuffled in, holding my stomach, bent over and clearly in the final stages of hunger-pains. After having placed my order and being greeted by almost all of the friendly clientele and staff the curry arrived. A light opened up above me, trumpets sounded, a harp was gently plucked. And I may or may not have taken a nose-dive into the curry.  Look, I'm sensitive to heat and so this burnt my throat and mouth to a point of angst-ridden pain but it was soooo good that despite the pain, I couldn't stop eating. (My fault for trusting them when they said there were very few chillies in there, "almost none").  What am I saying? I'm saying get your bee-hinds over here and have ye some curry! Doesn't get better, really doesn't, and they're so incredibly friendly. As a matter of fact, why .. I do believe it's almost lunch-time .... muahhahaha

nTlulKitrK-s_lQE9IZDtg.text: I do not get the hype here. The food was at best average. It is not a hole in the wall... And it is definitely not fast food. It is just a mediocre restaurant. The food was SO oily that I am pretty sure it seeped through our plastic bag. We ordered the mixed vegetable curry, the mushroom bhaji and the tarka dhal. I honestly could not taste much as my mouth was coated in oil. We also waited 20 minutes and watched 8 people who came in after us get their take away before us and get served before while sitting down. No explanation, no apology for how long it took and the fact that we got frog-jumped by everyone and their mothers. The lamb kebab was ok, but coming here was my biggest regret of our trip.

odCOEJ2iZ7XyZpEAbXrCnw.text: Damn, I thought this place was a secret.   This place is what Yelp was made for. If you did not know - you would probably would not bother.   This place is no secret to folks who love decent curries. Lots of regulars from the local Indian community to be found here and always some student newbies, occasionally with American accents.   Mister Khan is really nice fellow and his friends in the back make tremendous curries. You could just wander in here and get a kebab or some pakora. However, the folks who know will sit in the back, get yourself a lovely beverage (no alcohol served - like all of the best Indian restaurants) and enjoy the fabulous curries. The portions are immense and the curries and breads are always well made.    Finally, when you leave the price will startle you. It is stupidly low priced.   Wouldn't it be great if all of the places that looked Kebab Mahal were this good. A nasty looking off-license with a security screen had some lovely Chimay or Gambrinus in the beer chiller? Or a cheap cafe that served the greatest breakfast ever?   So, I told you - yeah it is great - now don't spoil it.

ovvzVJlCSRqa1Gikkr-zpg.text: I love Kebab Mahal. A regular haunt of mine, and everyone who likes desi food in Edinburgh from tourists, to professionals to students. It's a favourite, situation in Nicolson Square on Edinburgh's southside, well known for it's South Asian and Middle Eastern food scene, Kebab Mahal is definitely worth a visit. It is low key, unapologetic in it's roots, and dishes up the tastiest curries in Edinburgh.  It loses a star for having such a small seating area (it's really a diner/takeaway with a few seats) but again, that really is just part of it's charm. The pizza and pakora leaves something to be desired, but if you're coming here you really should be having the amazing curries and biryanis on offer.

g7estdVPmfRn9N8YiYFdaw.text: Food usually ranges from fair to very good. Try to avoid busy weekend afternoons. Service goes from non existent to terrible, probably because "waiters" come from Zombieland, and just because of that I'm not eating there as often as I did. A couple of times I ordered a lamb biryani and after waiting 45+ minutes I needed to leave and go to another carry out as I was starving, or, you order a main course + a garlic nan...but the nan bread never appeared. Sometimes you place an order but the waiter does not even go to the kitchen to pass it!!! Approximately 4 years ago they used the finest basmati rice, but after that rice crisis in South East Asia (when rice prices doubled up) the owner changed to a cheaper version of it and that drop in quality was very noticeable. Also by talking to regulars & tourists..the complain is always the same...food takes ages to get to you. In any case if it's not that busy you may have a good meal at a very affordable price...but don't go there if you are in a hurry. Hope it helps

rw7PIP8uaxfF2B5Y9G4Ojw.text: Tasty food for a reasonable price.  Not the nicest venue however if I lived in Edinburgh I would frequent this place for sure.

5ODIfZmFwQT6-0UgHRA7QA.text: Tipsy and craving some delicious nighttime kebab?  Kebab Mahal will be there for you with a delicious doener filled with greasy meat, drippy sauces, and garlic breath the next morning.  Kinda grotty and not the absolute best doener place in Edinburgh, but it will forever hold a special place in my heart (and likely my arteries).

q8orSvnS2D-6iRYGsRIruw.text: I would call this little gem one of Edinburgh's hidden secrets: although judging by all the positive comments on here perhaps it's not that well hidden? From the outside it looks like a ropey kebab shop, but step inside and you'll be treated to some of the best Indian food in town. The naan breads are big soft pillows and the currys are bursting with flavour (yes, even the korma!)

SvzdiSK9QrqJxE2g99ZW_A.text: I had heard amazing things about this kebab house, but not being a kebab lover myself  I didn't know how to judge it. I was surprised at how tasty the meat was - I didn't think the huge chunk of meat on the spit looked appetizing until it was sliding down my throat.  I must admit I've only been once and it was following a rather liquid lunch, but I'll be back and explore the menu further....but so far so very, very good!

aq_ycUkcmxl3C0RVTVO6ZA.text: Hands-down my favourite Indian place in Edinburgh.  The lamb bhuna is amazing.  Aside from near-perfect food, the atmosphere is nice, and the owner is a very gracious man who is eager to take care of his patrons.  I miss eating there, and it will be atop my list of eateries when I return to the 'Burgh.  And if you haven't tried it, their Baklava is the best I've ever had, and only about a quid per piece.

Y0FKd8pAeMl79kwqLOXWBA.text: This is just a tiny place run by a few guys, but it gets packed and is well worth squeezing in. We had some fantastic samosa to start, then dove into tikka masala and lamb bhuna, both of which were amazing. Price was shockingly reasonable, cheap even. Hard not to love.

0xZ4ahDQL94xNBAcAE1fXQ.text: I've only been to Kebab Mahal once and that was the first night after I moved into my new flat last summer.  Four of us turned up and waited for about five minutes for a table because it was well beyond maximum capacity as it was so busy.  I ordered the lamb balti with rice and a naan and we were eventually seated.  The atmosphere is particularly special as it is ethnically diverse with cool music and amazing smells wafting from the kitchen.  It was a very fortunate thing that it had a good atmosphere because we literally waited for about an 45 minutes for our food arrive, but when it did it was well worth it.   The lamb was good quality with virtually no sinuous or fatty bits amongst it and the flavour of the sauce was delicious.  It was seriously spicy, but my flatmate ordered the chicken madras which blew my head off after just a mouthful and he was literally dripping with sweat after about five minutes of eating it.  Kebab Mahal serves authentic Indian food at relatively cheap prices and is definitely worth a visit for an amazing dinner any night of the week.  As the name suggests they specialise in kebabs and, although I haven't tried them myself, they're meant to be incredible.

photos.caption: Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

EOk7z1lnpZud9PcZmKeudQ.text: Decadent.  Sumptous.  Mouth-watering.  Exquisite.  Superlatives really do struggle to adequately describe just how good the food is at Kebab Mahal. While their kebabs are approximately one million times better than the sweat soaked doners you'll find in 3am joints, it's the curries that really take the biscuit. Quite simply, they are the best I've ever eaten.   Talking about them doesn't do them justice, you simply have to try one for yourself.

29g6sI3KGl60H4kFr9zgTw.text: I have always been a big fun of kebab mahal. I love the red sauce. Great food. Service can be slaw sometimes.

NCxRMt5--HTnu47MYSNCQg.text: We made a beeline here after the rave reviews and, forewarned, we weren't expecting a fancy place. Maybe it was because we were looking forward to it so much that our expectations were somewhat dimmed. The food was generally average, we felt. My Vindaloo was spicy enough but the meat was a bit tough and, temperature-wise, could've done with being hotter. The naan was not great and didn't seem fresh or have that "just cooked" fluffiness. Service was adequate, but slow, as there was a steady stream of people picking up takeouts. You help yourself to soft drinks from a chiller at the back. The prices were reasonable. Sorry, other lovers of this place, but Mother India is miles better (and not a lot more expensive) so we'll be sticking to that, or Kebabish.

wGfujZ1ec2UN_ZYIPV7Yeg.text: I'm sad this place is so well known I thought it was my friends and I , are own little secret ,but since the cat is out of the bag I am Yelping it. This place is hands down the best Curry shop in the whole city. It's the perfect little hole-in-the-wall and when I first walked by it I took one look at it and KNEW this place was going to be good. My Saudi friend then took my here and I was hooked! I was ready to come wash dishes in exchange for food! What can I recommend? All of it seriously , but the creme of the crop is....Chicken Tikka Masala. The creamy sauce with the melt in your mouth chicken ....drool..... Sooooooo good. The owner is the kindly Gentleman with the big white beard so if you see him tell him how wonderful his food is and his establishment ,because I always always see him working there and all that hard work has paid off to blossom this place into the best curry this side of India or Pakistan hands down!

GFLEIeYWzIPDeBR8t-eD2g.text: Helllllllllllllllllo kebab mahal......you tryin to make me fat??? so goood...one day i'll come to this restaurant not be able to leave the food is so bang on!

Cr-Zzx_QPkb5zAq6Wyfuyw.text: On our (me and hubby) two day visit to Edinburgh, this was one of the best finds. A hole in the wall kinda restaurant, seems to be very busy and dishes out absolutely lip smacking dishes with ease. We had been to Kebab Mahal twice and both the times we loved the food. If you are one of those people who prefer posh restaurants over good food, then my friend this place is not for you. This place looks more like a fast food joint but but but.... the food is nothing like fast food. The two times we were here we tried the shammi kebab, chicken tandoori, chicken bhuna, kharahi murgh accompanied with super yummy tandoori garlic naan. All the dishes including the naan was absolutely delicious. At the end after you have stuffed yourself with these goodies, if you still have any room left for dessert do try the baklava. Best baklavas i have ever tasted. We also tried the almond cake which was also yummmm. Delicious food, excellent service and warm & welcoming staff = awesome gastronomic experience.

LQqzPfgIFq66vXu1dy47Hw.text: This restaurant is very dodgy looking and in sore need of a refurbishment.   The food however, is excellent. And ridiculously good value.   Very tasty curries with more choice than the Mosque Kitchen, but also very cheap.

iVgpuO7Jmp23eKw96EpzDA.text: We've been staying at the house of an Indian chef and got this place recommended as great place to have some proper Pakistani and Indian cuisine in town. And boy, it was delicious.   Don't expect haute cuisine dining or even proper seating, this is a small joint where the curries steal all the fame. We had Chicken Karahi, Naan, Keema Rice and tried some more stuff from a friendly Scottish guest who was a regular here.   The only thing I personally didn't like was the mixed appetizer plate which was precooked and not crunchy anymore. It didn't pass the excellence test in my book. Yet, there is an infinite amount of two chutneys to go along with the main dishes, so I'd call it a draw.   The owners are a friendly bunch and you won't leave this place with an empty stomach, so if you are in need of a good, proper spice cuisine, stop by and throw some money at this place. You won't regret it, it's great.

hgL3DOewt-1BP_sr9HHRnQ.text: Vegetarian side dish portions were too small for 4.50. Also, there were only the owner and one extra waiter serving customers. This was insufficient for the (busy) lunch time and service took a bit too long. They should hire extra staff. Decent place otherwise.

KhxtNUk-2YXvlElPHK9zqA.text: The food here was great, but the ambiance makes it a food best enjoyed as takeaway. The line and overall busy-ness of the cafe is a testament to the quality, but it is jam packed and there isn't really anywhere to stand without being in the way while waiting for a seat or your food.  There are lots of food choices, and everything we ordered tasted wonderful. I even took the rest of the naan in a napkin in my pocket to have as a snack for later, i liked it so much. Definitely try the yogurt and chili sauces they bring out-they really add to the meal.

8bDfUblNhya25eVsq5l-2A.text: The food tasted great. BUT, after a couple hours my stomach began to get quite upset. Without going into detail I had way too many trips to the bathroom after eating there...

a-9mx7hfogJuBe4RFhjAog.text: I loved the food here. As they say dont judge the book by the cover, dont judge this place by the looks and the board which boasts pizza and doner kebab on it. The food is good authentic indian and tandoori food cooked brilliantly and is cheap.  The service is friendly and of course extra friendly for me as I could speak the language :-) The saag panner was excellent as was the bhindi masala. The samosa was spicy and the rotis were huge.  Tried the special tea and raas malai for dessert and it was excellent. In fact the dessert was the favourite part of my meal. All up with three courses it was 30 quid for two to have dinner including drinks. Not bad for what was a big meal.   I would drop in here regularly if I could :-)

photos.caption: Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom
Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

EE5ryP-R2HU5MNI13sF0AQ.text: Ghee in all of the vegetarian dishes making them not vegan friendly.   Owners or operators not willing to make without ghee. Vegetable oil costs less and is likely better for you, so why not make the exception for vegans?  The menu further states that they will make you any curry if you ask, even if it isn't on the menu. Apparently they can't make one without ghee.  No money from me.

19B7o_EziP8WEjhCtMO-2A.text: Delicious! The Chicken Tikka Masala is the best I've ever had. The Chicken Biryani is also excellent and a very large serving. Has efficient table service. Overall a very good value.

reEk59CL7PG3XIIYctKNTg.text: Me and 2 friends were looking for dinner options in Edinburgh and found this place on yelp. We wanted something good and something affordable. This place was both! It was first time having Indian food ever and this place set the bar really high. We visited Edinburgh for 9 days and ate here 3 times.

photos.caption: Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. DELICIOUS

Qo8SRMDK088TQfaTkQLX3g.text: Nothing more to add than the others have said, it's great. Surprisingly extensive menu, unbeatable prices, convenient.

photos.caption: Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom. Tandoori takeaway. Not all good things are pretty.
Photo of Kebab Mahal - Edinburgh, United Kingdom

8sPtCANZ2JxdLN9nbJi9_g.text: Oh my goodness this place is great! The staff are wonderful, the price is even better and the food is superb. A definite favourite go to, would eat here anytime type place.   We usually get takeout, but there is a place to sit and eat which is useful if your buttling around that part of town.

bBn67SpB-wAxUwnf8Bx35A.text: The food and service at this restaurant was awesome. Both dishes that we ordered were just excellent. The staff was very friendly and accommodating. We will definitely go back again if we are in the area. Great value for the money.

enoGrOvvp57wCuRpShLJtQ.text: They absolutely ruined our dinner. No attention to any detail and if you order in you are on your own. They expect you to make your own kebab and give you far less. I am a loyal customer turned against after an embarrassingly bad visit with people visiting the city. Never again. Screw this place.

rrfRV-rYQWAlql_-_lLx0Q.text: Erm.... This place is amazing.   I've heard about the Kebab Mahal on the Edinburgh grapevine for years. But for some reason I never felt the need to go there. But now I always feel the need to go there. Because the food is fantastic. And oh, so cheap.   This is not a posh restaurant. Oh no. It's formica tables and stools and weird items stuffed up the back of the room. There's even two parts to the place, separated by a proper wall and accessible only by going outside and entering another main door. This is what I like to call personality.   Me and my other half had an incredible meal here, in the completely separate restaurant from everyone else. We ordered a starter of onion bhajis (three arrived the size of steering wheels) followed by a veritable feast of Indian main courses. I opted for two sides and a naan to keep me filled and the bloke opted for a main course, rice, naan and a side.   We couldn't finish it all and took the rest home. All that wonderful food only came to 26. And the service was good too - our waiter was pleasant and we even helped him shift some tables to accommodate us.   It felt like a mad family meal - will absolutely, definitely, totally be back for more. Long live Kebab Mahal!

Hy8WNmR7X-cdGCiVNpA3Rw.text: So CHEAP and so GOOD!!!! I love this place! It is not the coziest restaurant in the world, but man, the food is awesome! The kebab reminded me my days in Istanbul. Perfect combination of meat, veggetables and spices. I cannot wait to come back!

0Nceg63h8d6wBgN7_--frw.text: Excellent curry in a family run establishment with a total of six tables.    The service is quick and the food is great.  We had chicken tikka masala (excellent) and lamb bhuna (very good).   Thank you, Yelpsters, for a great tip.

qSxtDfkBkKbBSv3PkzB3rA.text: Do not judge a book by its cover. And certainly do NOT judge Kebab Mahal by its appearance!   It will reward you with one delightful indian food experience. From the chicken tikka karahi to lamb tikka bhuna, every plate is delicious and generous on  the size. Accompanied with a couple of nans and you have an unforgettable ethnic feast! Our meal ended with a baklava and a kataifi which was equally delicious and we hardly reached a 24 bill.   Best Indian in Edinburgh for sure, and if you know the cardinality of the set "Indian restaurants in Edinburgh", that says a lot.

WyMfiGXggagZlseNZ6r2pA.text: Very good takeaway kebabs (Afghani or Pakistani style) with a few seats in the restaurant. The proprietors are very friendly making this a great place for a simple, cheap meal.

60J21GZfY2ED1o2PtWgNWg.text: This is an addiction. If I am put into rehab for this addiction I will escape, and find my way back to the palace of Indian food in Edinburgh known as Kebab Mahal.  The Taj Mahal has nothing on Kebab Mahal. In fact, seeking asylum in this Mahal will do you much better than the other Mahal. The inscription at the Taj Mahal was obviously mistakenly put there when it was meant to be here, at Kebab Mahal:  "Should guilty seek asylum here, Like one pardoned, he becomes free from sin. Should a sinner make his way to this mansion, All his past sins are to be washed away. The sight of this mansion creates sorrowing sighs; And the sun and the moon shed tears from their eyes. In this world this edifice has been made; To display thereby the creator's glory."  Wash away your past sins by eating at this mansion of Halal traditional tandoori and curry dishes. For it is here that you will be pardoned.

GgneC8xNH_5sT6Ax7ZUsvw.text: Cheap curries.  The chicken and mushroom was nice.  Big chunks of white meat chicken.  Sis liked the chicken tikka masala.  I thought it was too rich and creamy, but I like mine more "tomatey" and sis doesn't.  The aubergine was drenched in oil.  Tasty, but super greasy. The naan was huuuuge.  It was 4 times the size of the naan that I had at London restaurant.  We did experience the MSG thirst a couple of hours after dinner though.   The doner kebab is horrifying.  Yes, it's HUGE, but the "meat" is dry and awful and the whole thing was drenched in a neon red sauce that just ended up disintegrating the pita bread into a mushy red mess.  Don't get that on clothing. You'll never get it out.   Popular place for local students.  Come at the wrong time and you'll be waiting a while.  Call ahead with your order as they advise on the website.   Would return, but only for the curries.

Md-EIVgkOydbYqR4rDzilg.text: It would be easy to mistake Kebab Mahal for just another place that sells processed shaved meats, its unassuming and dated appearance not doing it any favours however the old saying is True - one should not judge a book by it's cover...  The food is excellent - from the mild rich and creamy chicken tikka masala to the more spicy madras or vindaloo which have a good balance of heat and flavour and real kebabs. The only thing ever to take me by surprise is that the chicken pakora is on the bone - delicious but something to be aware of.  To sum up, yes it can be very busy, is small and looks dated however if you want good food at a good price Kebab Mahal is one of the best places to get a curry in Edinburgh and I for one hope it never changes.
